properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch & Act is being issued for the Lower Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.

  • Flooding continues to occur in the Lower Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.
  • Releases from Kow Swamp into the Pyramid Creek have been reduced now that inflows to Kow Swamp have significantly decreased.
  • The peak of the Bullock Creek inflows and Kow Swamp releases are now downstream of the Milnes Bridge area, heading towards the Kerang-Koondrook Road.
  • This peak is staying around properties for up to three days.
  • Floodwaters may continue to impact properties along the Pyramid Creek from Kow Swamp to Kerang area.
  • Further rises are expected downstream from Milnes Bridge to Kerang over the next three to six days.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Farmers in low-lying areas should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Follow your emergency plan and locate your emergency kit, if you have one.
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters. Check the https://traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/ website for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Stay away from damaged and flooded buildings, fallen or damaged trees and powerlines, and damaged roads until authorities advise they are safe.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Kerang-Murrabit Road is closed due to floodwater. 
  • Other local roads and bridges are closed due to flooding. 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
Snakes:
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.   
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.   
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. 
  • If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately. 
Mosquito alert
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes)
Infectious diseases:
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness. 
  • Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected.
  • Find out more  Better Health (Emergencies - floods)
Mould:
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. 
  • For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home)
Flood-affected septic systems:
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include:
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked
  • Tanks and sumps
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/11/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Flood Advice is being issued for Lalbert Creek from Lake Lalbert to Lake Tiboram.

  • Floodwaters from the Avoca River are flowing down Lalbert Creek, between Lake Lalbert and Lake Tiboram.
  • The bank of the creek has been breached in some areas, causing flooding in low-lying areas adjacent to Lalbert Creek.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers in low-lying areas should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area:
  • High water levels and flooding may occur in areas close to the Lalbert Creek.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
Snakes: 
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.   
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.   
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. 
  • If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately.    
Mosquito alert: 
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. 
  • There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.  Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected. 
  • Find out more, visit: Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 
Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  • For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit: Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
 If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
This message was issued by State Emergency Service 

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last Flood Advice for this event.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (Vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Support for flood impacted farmers and producers
  • Farmers who require support to prepare for flooding, who have been impacted by floods and require assistance or have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226
  • For further information on managing crops and livestock after a flood, budget feed plans, and other support and assistance, visit agriculture.vic.gov.au
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte.

The Yarra River catchment has recorded rainfall averaging about 11 mm in the upper part of the catchment and about 2 mm in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Monday 07 November 2022. Rainfall totals of 5-20 mm with isolated 40-50 mm due to potential thunderstorms activities are forecast for the catchment for Tuesday 08 November 2022.

Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte:

The level of the Yarra River at Yarra Glen is currently at 4.45 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (4.10 metres), and falling. It is expected to rise again towards the Moderate Flood Level (4.60 metres) on Wednesday evening (09 November 2022).

Minor to Moderate flooding in the Yarra River catchment is expected to cause substantial inundation in the rural and/or urban areas, and disruption to traffic.
Prepare for flooding now. Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
Community Infrastructure that may flood include:
  • Yarra Glen Recreation Reserve and Showgrounds 
  • Yarra Glen Racecourse 
  • Yarra Flats Billabongs pedestrian bridge and internal track
  • Spadoni’s Nature Reserve
Water over the road is likely on the Melba Highway between Lilyponds Creek Bridge and Yarra Glen.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Werribee River to Melton Reservoir.

The Werribee River catchment has experienced thunderstorm activity this afternoon with high isolated rainfall totals observed in the region. Rainfall totals of 5-20 mm and the potential for more isolated thunderstorms are forecast for the catchment Wednesday 09 November 2022.

Werribee River to Melton Reservoir:

The level of the Werribee River at Ballan is currently steady at 0.90 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (1.20 metres). If rainfall occurs as forecast the water level at this location could rise to the Minor Flood Level again.

The level of the Werribee River at Bacchus Marsh is currently steady at 1.15 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (4.40 metres). Following isolated storm activity in the area today, it peaked around 2.00 metres earlier this evening.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Be wary of river edges, they may subside. 
  • Cyclists and walkers should be wary of tracks next to rivers. 
  • Canoeists should avoid all flood waters.  
  • Recreational boaters need to be aware of increased river outfalls.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Minor flooding in the Werribee River catchment is expected to affect low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT MCKILLOPS BRIDGE

MINOR FLOODING MAY DEVELOP AT DOWNSTREAM (D/S) OF BASIN CREEK OVERNIGHT TUESDAY 

Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River at McKillops Bridge and minor flooding may develop downstream of Basin Creek overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. Flooding is not expected to extend further downstream to Jarrahmond and Orbost.

Releases from Lake Jindabyne are currently 10,000 ML/d and are expected to remain around this level for the next few days.

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge: 
Minor flooding may occur along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River D/S Basin Creek is currently at 3.45 metres and rising slowly. The Snowy River D/S Basin Ck is likely to reach the minor flood level (3.50 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.

This update replaces the Advice message issued at 11.12am 7/11/2022.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Impacts in your area: 

  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au. 
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater. 
  • Recent rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides – be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton

This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 1.04pm  Monday 7/11/2022

Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.

The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 9.57 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 

The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge will remain above the minor flood level (9.00 m) during Tuesday and into Wednesday

MCCOYS BRIDGE IS CLOSED TO ALL TRAFFIC INCLUDING FOOT TRAFFIC.

Goulburn Murray Water has advised that releases from Lake Eildon will be around 20,000 ML/d during Tuesday, below the moderate flood flow.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 12 mm have been recorded within the Goulburn River catchment. 

No significant rainfall is forecast for the the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday

Flood Recovery Community Information Session for BUNBARTHA and District - Tuesday 8th November 5.30pm.  To be held at Bunbartha Community Centre (Tennis Courts) 10 Loch Garry Road, Bunbartha


Community information:

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent, for more info please visit Better Health (Mosquitoes)

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases.  

In flood-affected areas, there are now many cases of gastro (gastroenteritis, diarrhoea) causing people to get very sick.   To information on how to prevent gastro visit Better Health (Gastro)

Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home. Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas. 
  
Illegal levees
In response to a number of concerns raised by community members, landowners are reminded that construction of works to divert the overland flow of water requires approval. To construct levees that interfere with overland water flows, without obtaining approval, is likely to impact on others and is also likely to be deemed illegal. 

We acknowledge these are difficult times for each impacted member of the community however, it is not appropriate to interfere with the natural overland flow of water as it can negatively impact on others. 


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

Do not camp or go bush driving close to rivers or creeks.  

Unexpected river and creek levels are very likely even with small amounts of rain.   
Support the local towns and make sure to set a watch zone for your location this long weekend and regularly check emergency radio broadcasters ( eg ABC radio) via your car radio if necessary.

Be aware of the increased likelihood of trees falling due to the very wet ground, especially in windy conditions. Never shelter under trees.    

Don't go fishing, kayaking, or boating. Floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater
  • In flood-affected areas, there are now many cases of gastro (gastroenteritis, diarrhoea) causing people to get very sick.   To prevent gastro always wash your hands after going to the toilet, before eating, preparing food, or cleaning your teeth etc. Only drink and wash, or wash clothes in known clean water.   Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home.  Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted area
  •  Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water. Smelly black water can be reported to EPA on 1800 560 760
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
When returning home:
  • Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property. 
  •  If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician.  
  •  If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician.  
  •  For more information visit: https://esv.vic.gov.au/safety-education/emergencies/electrical-emergency/ Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
  •  Follow your emergency plan and locate your emergency kit, if you have one.
  • If cleaning after damage has occurred, protect your health and safety. 
  • Protect your lungs by wearing a N95 or P2 mask. 
  • Wear strong boots, gloves and protective clothing and wash your hands and clothes regularly.
  •  Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  •  Smelly black water can be reported to EPA on 1800 560 760
Generators

If you are using a generator, do not attempt to connect it to the wiring of your home. This is dangerous and illegal.

A generator should only be used outside, with an extension cord to supply power direct to appliances such as the fridge or freezer. Using a generator indoors creates a number of safety risks including the potential for carbon monoxide poisoning or a fire. 
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Many local roads may still be closed and low bridges may still be underwater.
  • The Murray Valley Highway is fully closed at Mc Coys Bridge due to Bridge damage.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Don't go fishing, kayaking, or boating. Floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Shepparton Community Recovery Hub is located at the Shepparton Senior Citizens Centre, Welsford Street Shepparton. Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday 10am to 4pm. Thursday 12pm to 6pm (Check opening hours on the Greater Shepparton Council Facebook page)

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.  
Recovery: 
 Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: Register for clean up on private property; Navigating financial and other support Access to temporary accommodation Mental health and wellbeing support The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 or visit www.erv.vic.gov.au for further information. For life-threatening emergencies, call Triple Zero (000) immediately. For emergency assistance during floods call 132 500 for SES assistance.

Shepparton Community Recovery Hub is located at the Shepparton Senior Citizens Centre, Welsford Street Shepparton. Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday 10am to 4pm. Thursday 12pm to 6pm (Check opening hours on the Greater Shepparton Council Facebook page)

Health Messaging 
  • Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home. 
  • Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas. 
  •  Stay out of the water - skin contact with floodwater or mud can cause illness and skin infections. Cover cuts and if you are injured during your clean up; clean the wound and contact your doctor immediately.  
  •  Private water supplies may also be contaminated from floodwater, debris and chemicals. If your water supply tastes, looks or smells unusual, do not use it for drinking, preparing food, and do not give it to animals.  Medicines, stored at home and affected by flood water may now be unsafe and extreme caution should be taken in trying to salvage any medicines.  
  •  Any damaged gas or electricity supplies need to be declared safe by a qualified electrician or plumber. Do not use a portable generator indoors, they can produce carbon monoxide gas which could build up in a confined space and make you sick or be fatal. 
  •  Food safety should also be considered and ALL food that has been flood damaged should be thrown away including canned and packaged foods. 
  •  It is important to look after your mental health and that of friends, family and neighbours. If at any time you are worried about your mental health or the mental health of a loved one, call Lifeline 13 11 14 or the Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467.

Register Find Unite - Red Cross 
Red Cross has opened Register.Find.Reunite. and is urging people affected by the Victorian Floods to get in touch with their families and friends. Register.Find.Reunite. helps find and reunite family, friends and loved ones during a disaster. People can register on the Red Cross website at register.redcross.org.au, or by phone at 1800 727 077. This is a community message to advise the community not to build own levees as it changes the flow of the water and impacting other properties.
properties.text: ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed Incident Location: Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton Issue Date: Tuesday 08 November 2022, 12:17 pm Next Update: Wednesday 09 November 2022, 02:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/26425/moreinfo This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 1.04pm Monday 7/11/2022 Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton: Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton. The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 9.57 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge will remain above the minor flood level (9.00 m) during Tuesday and into Wednesday MCCOYS BRIDGE IS CLOSED TO ALL TRAFFIC INCLUDING FOOT TRAFFIC. Goulburn Murray Water has advised that releases from Lake Eildon will be around 20,000 ML/d during Tuesday, below the moderate flood flow. In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 12 mm have been recorded within the Goulburn River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday Flood Recovery Community Information Session for BUNBARTHA and District - Tuesday 8th November 5.30pm. To be held at Bunbartha Community Centre (Tennis Courts) 10 Loch Garry Road, Bunbartha Community information: Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould) Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent, for more info please visit Better Health (Mosquitoes) Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility. Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases. In flood-affected areas, there are now many cases of gastro (gastroenteritis, diarrhoea) causing people to get very sick. To information on how to prevent gastro visit Better Health (Gastro) Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home. Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas. Illegal levees In response to a number of concerns raised by community members, landowners are reminded that construction of works to divert the overland flow of water requires approval. To construct levees that interfere with overland water flows, without obtaining approval, is likely to impact on others and is also likely to be deemed illegal. We acknowledge these are difficult times for each impacted member of the community however, it is not appropriate to interfere with the natural overland flow of water as it can negatively impact on others. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert. Do not camp or go bush driving close to rivers or creeks. Unexpected river and creek levels are very likely even with small amounts of rain. Support the local towns and make sure to set a watch zone for your location this long weekend and regularly check emergency radio broadcasters ( eg ABC radio) via your car radio if necessary. Be aware of the increased likelihood of trees falling due to the very wet ground, especially in windy conditions. Never shelter under trees. Don't go fishing, kayaking, or boating. Floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers.

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT DOWNSTREAM LAKE EILDON, TRAWOOL, SEYMOUR,MURCHISON, SHEPPARTON AND MCCOYS BRIDGE

Minor flooding is continuing along the Goulburn River at Downstream Lake Eildon, Trawool, Seymour, Murchison, Shepparton and McCoys Bridge.

Goulburn Murray Water has advised that releases from Lake Eildon will be around 20,000 ML/d during Tuesday, below the moderate flood flow.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 12 mm have been recorded within the Goulburn River catchment.

No significant rainfall is forecast for the the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday

Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour. Minor flooding is occurring at Trawool.

The Goulburn River downstream Lake Eildon is currently at 3.64 metres and steady, with minor flooding. 

The Goulburn River downstream Lake Eildon is likely to remain around 3.65 metres during Tuesday and into Wednesday(minor flood level 3.00 m).

The Goulburn River at Seymour is currently at 4.97 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. The Goulburn River at Seymour is expected to remain above the minor flood level (3.80 m) during Tuesday and into Wednesday. 


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Community Information:     

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)   

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent, for more information visit Better Health (Mosquitoes)

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility. Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases.   

Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home. Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas.   
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction to Liparoo.
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction to Liparoo.

Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray River and its tributaries. Water levels are expected to stay high for a few weeks, due to widespread rain over NSW and Victoria and saturated catchment soils. 

  • Major flooding is occurring at Wakool Junction. The Murray River at Wakool Junction may reach near 12.00 metres around 13 to 15 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • Moderate flooding is occurring at Boundary Bend. The Murray River at Boundary Bend may exceed the major flood level (9.00 metres) around Friday 11 November. The river level may reach near 9.10 metres around 15 to 17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • The Murray River at Euston may exceed the moderate flood level (9.80 metres, 51.60 metresAHD) around 13-16 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (10.30 metres, 52.10 metres AHD) around 16 to 18 November and reach around 10.40 metres (52.24 metres AHD) around 19 to 22 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
Significant breakout flows from Torrumbarry have spilled into the Wakool River. These flows, combined with floodwaters from the Murray and Edward Rivers, have caused major flooding at Wakool Junction and may cause major flooding downstream at Boundary Bend, Euston (Robinvale), Mildura and Wentworth, with levels higher than the 1975 flood event. Moderate flooding is occurring at Wentworth.

Forecasts will be progressively refined once the upstream flood peaks along the Murray River and its tributaries are observed.

Some properties in rural areas may be isolated due to standing water. Aircraft (including drones) are being used to determine the extent of water inundation across the area. Emergency services personnel are assessing impacts on affected properties caused by overtopping and levee breeches.

Emergency services are assessing and reinforcing existing levees as required, protecting isolated assets and providing relief to local communities and primary producers.  The evaluation of potential impacts on critical infrastructure and townships remains a focus.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
Never allow children to play in or near floodwater! 
  • Flooded rivers and creeks can contain toxic chemicals such as petrol, oil, animal or human waste, pesticides and runoff from roads, paddocks, drains and even sewage overflows (poo and wee and anything else that is flushed down the toilet).
  • Raw sewage and floodwater can contain bacteria and viruses like E Coli, Giardia and Hepatitis A. Swallowing even a small amount of this can make your children sick. Open cuts, grazes and wounds can easily become infected.
  • Barbed wire, rubbish, branches, broken glass, metal fragments and other loose items can all find their way into floodwater. These objects can cause a child to get tangled or severely injured. They could lose their footing and strain a muscle, roll an ankle or they could fall and be knocked unconscious.   
Floodwater is dangerous. Stay safe - never enter floodwater. 

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Support for flood impacted farmers and producers:
  • Farmers who require support to prepare for flooding, who have been impacted by floods and require assistance or have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
  • For further information on managing crops and livestock after a flood, including budget feed plans, and other support and assistance, visit agriculture.vic.gov.au

Impacts in your area:

  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home may occur in some locations.
  • Levees may overtop in some areas.
  • High river levels may cause flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Some agricultural land may be vulnerable to flooding. Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Local roads may be closed. For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • An Emergency Warning - Evacuate Immediately message is current for Kenley. 
  • Floodwaters at Boundary Bend are currently around 8.80m. It is expected the river will exceed major flood levels around 11 November and peak around 15 to 17 November.  
  • The Murray River at Robinvale is currently around 51.9m and rising. It is predicted that floodwaters will reach major levels by mid-November with further rises possible. Crews are undertaking pre-emptive levee construction and sandbagging at Tol Tol. 
  • The Murray River at Wemen is currently at 47.68m and rising. Levee construction and sandbagging is being carried out.
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
Murray River Closure:  
  • The Murray River is closed to river craft downstream of Tocumwal Bridge to Robinvale. People and boats are prohibited from entering the river between these locations. 
  • Any person on the Murray between these points are to leave the river.  This declaration applies to all residents on both sides of the border.
  • Neither NSW or Victorian users are permitted on the river at this time.  
Snakes: 
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately. 
Mosquito alert 
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. 
  •  There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.  
  •  Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected. 
  •  Find out more, visit:  Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 
Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  • For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
Blackwater event:   
Significant rainfall and flooding can cause water quality issues like low-oxygen (hypoxic) blackwater and blue green algae. High levels of organic matter have been washed into waterways and, combined with warm weather, can cause oxygen levels in the water to drop. This can harm or cause the death of fish and crayfish. River managers and scientists monitor rivers for water quality issues and work to reduce the impacts of a blackwater event where they can. Low levels of dissolved oxygen are recorded at several locations across northern Victoria and in the Murray River. The scale of the current flooding means water quality will not improve quickly. Any fish death event in Victoria should be reported to the EPA by calling 1300 372 842. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT MCKILLOPS BRIDGE

MINOR FLOODING MAY DEVELOP AT DOWNSTREAM (D/S) BASIN CREEK OVERNIGHT TUESDAY

Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River at McKillops Bridge and minor flooding may develop at Downstream (D/S) Basin Creek overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. Flooding is not expected to extend further downstream to Jarrahmond and Orbost.

Releases from Lake Jindabyne are currently 10,000 ML/d and are expected to remain around this level for the next few days. 

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge: 
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is currently at 2.83 metres and rising, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) for the remainder of Tuesday through to Thursday.  
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Recent rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides – be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River downstream of Wandocka.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT SALE WHARF

In the 24 hours to 3:00 pm Monday no significant rainfall totals have been recorded over the Thomson River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Releases are continuing from Lake Glenmaggie and the river level downstream along the Thomson River at Sale Wharf is rising slowly above the minor flood level.

Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:

Thomson River at Sale Wharf is currently at 2.66 metres and rising slowly. The Thomson River at Sale Wharf may reach around 2.75 metres during Monday. 

The river level is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.40 m) for next few days.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.

This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Ovens River downstream of Rocky Point. 

FLOODING HAS EASED AT WANGARATTA

  • Minor flooding has eased along the Ovens River at Wangaratta.
  • No further flooding is expected in the Ovens River downstream of Rocky Point.
  • The Ovens River at Wangaratta fell below the minor flood level early Tuesday morning. 
  • The river level is currently at 11.81 metres and falling slowly. 
  • The Ovens River at Wangaratta is expected to remain below the minor flood level (11.90 m).
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Kenley.

  • An evacuation warning remains current. It is still not safe to return.
  • Floodwaters are continuing to rise along the Murray River downstream of Wakool Junction. 
  • Major flooding is occurring in Kenley, with floodwater continuing to rise to its peak over the coming week.
  • Hazards exist in and around the Kenley area. We strongly advise those planning to visit the area to make alternative arrangement.
It is not safe for people to return to Kenley. If you have not evacuated, leaving now is still the safest option.
Travel to a safe location such as:
  • Family or friends’ homes located in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • The Emergency Relief Centre in Swan Hill: The Stadium Swan Hill (Basketball Centre) 15 Gray Street, Swan Hill. Phone: 0447 094 347
When you leave:
  • The safest route to evacuate is via Coghill Road to Murray Valley Highway.
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone and medications.
If you have already evacuated:
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
If you stay: 
  • If you choose to stay, emergency services may not be able to help you. 
  • Stay inside and be aware of changing conditions. 
  • If floodwater comes inside, move to a higher point such as a kitchen bench or second story. 
  • Follow your emergency plan, if you have one. 
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so. 
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some areas. 
  • This flood may be similar to the 1956 flood event.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home.
  • Areas near the affected location may lose services including power, water, sewerage and phone coverage due to flooding.
  • Evacuating too late or choosing to remain in your home when recommended to evacuate is dangerous and may put your life at risk .
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham.

  • Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray and Edwards Rivers and their tributaries.
  • Releases from the Hume Dam combined with Kiewa River flows have caused moderate flooding along the Murray River at Tocumwal, where river levels are likely to remain steady over the next couple days.
  • Along the Murray River at Echuca and Moama, river levels are slowly receding, with major flooding likely to continue until around Wednesday. 
  • At Torrumbarry, river levels are expected to remain steady due to continuing breakout flows, with major flooding forecast into mid November.
  • At Barham, a major flood peak was observed around 26 October following a series of renewed rises. River levels are falling slowly, with major flooding likely to continue through to the end of the week. 
Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham:
  • Major flooding is occurring at Echuca, Moama, Torrumbarry and Barham.
  • The Murray River at Echuca peaked at 94.98 metres AHD on Wednesday 26 October and is currently at 94.55 metres AHD and falling slowly, with major flooding.
  • The Murray River at Echuca is likely to remain above the major flood level (94.40 metres) through to Wednesday.
  • The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is likely to remain around 7.85 metres through to mid November, with major flooding.
  • The Murray River at Barham peaked at 6.21 metres on Wednesday 26 October and is currently at 6.14 metres and steady, with major flooding. The Murray River at Barham is likely to remain above the major flood level (6.10 metres) through to the end of the week.
This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued Monday 7 November at 4:56pm.

There is an Evacuation Warning - Not Safe to Return in place for Echuca and Echuca Village.

The latest community newsletter from Monday 7 November is available here: Community Newsletter

Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary.
  • For commercial and recreational users of the Murray River: NSW State Emergency Services have declared an emergency area on the Murray River for areas downstream of Tocumal Bridge to Tooleybuc under the State Emergency Services Act 1989 (NSW) (SES Act). Do not enter the emergency area. This applies to all commercial and recreational users. Visit the NSW SES website for information: https://www.ses.nsw.gov.au/news/all-news/2022/murray-river-closure-emergency-area-extension
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • You may see animals attempting to move to higher ground, including snakes.
  • Leave all uninjured wildlife alone as they are likely to be fatigued and stressed.
  • If you see animals that appear injured or caught in flood water, call 136186 or via the Wildlife Emergency App
All public land including state and national parks, forests and reserves along the Murray downstream of Tocumwal to Barham are closed. Be aware that soft ground, erosion of roots and potential high winds can cause trees to fall.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Benjeroop to Wakool Junction
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Benjeroop to Wakool Junction.

Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray River and its tributaries. Water levels are expected to stay high for a few weeks, due to widespread rain over NSW and Victoria and saturated catchment soils.

  • Moderate flooding is occurring at Swan Hill and Boundary Bend.
  • Major flooding is occurring at Wakool Junction.
  • The Murray River at Swan Hill may peak near the major flood level (4.70 m) during Thursday, with major flooding. 
  • This has been revised down from 4.80m and is likely to be below the 1975 flood level.
  • The Murray River at Wakool Junction may reach near 12.00 metres around 13 to 15 November, with major flooding.
  • Further rises are possible.
Aircraft (including drones) are being used to determine the extent of water inundation across the area. 

Emergency services are assessing and reinforcing existing levees as required, protecting isolated assets and providing relief to local communities and primary producers.  The evaluation of potential impacts on critical infrastructure and townships remains a focus.
Prepare for flooding now. Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.
What you should do:
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Some agricultural land may be vulnerable to flooding. Farmers in low-lying areas should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways.
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels may cause flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-storey home is possible in some rural locations.
  • Local roads may be impacted by floodwater. For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.  
  • An Emergency Warning - Not Safe to Return message is current for Kenley.
  • Water levels along the Little Murray River at Fish Point are holding and steady. Further rises are possible, although nothing significant is expected at this time.
  • There are currently no risk or impacts to the Lake Boga community expected. Crews are working to rebuild and raise the existing levee. The Lake itself is currently at 81.78% capacity, up from 79.5% in July 20
  • Floodwaters at Pental Island are currently peaking at 71.64m and remaining steady. Crews are actively monitoring the levee, however don’t currently expect there to be any major issues with the integrity of the levee.
  • The Murray River at Swan Hill is now only expected to reach 4.70m (down from 4.80m) during Thursday. At this stage, emergency services have no concerns with the integrity of the Swan Hill Township levee. The levee is built to around 600mm above the 1% AEP event. Crews are working to reinforce the levee and sandbags in Speewa and Beverford. 
  • Water levels are being monitored at Piangil while levee works are being carried out to protect several properties in Wood Wood. 
  • Major flooding is occurring at Kenley with flood heights at Wakool Junction continuing to rise. Floodwaters may achieve record levels (11.9m) between 11 and 13 November with communities downstream expected to be impacted in the days following. Works to upgrade the levee at Kenley and sandbagging to protect local properties and agricultural assets are ongoing. 

Never allow children to play in or near floodwater! 
  • Flooded rivers and creeks can contain toxic chemicals such as petrol, oil, animal or human waste, pesticides and runoff from roads, paddocks, drains and even sewage overflows (poo and wee and anything else that is flushed down the toilet). 
  • Raw sewage and floodwater can contain bacteria and viruses like E Coli, Giardia and Hepatitis A. Swallowing even a small amount of this can make your children sick. Open cuts, grazes and wounds can easily become infected.
  • Barbed wire, rubbish, branches, broken glass, metal fragments and other loose items can all find their way into floodwater. These objects can cause a child to get tangled or severely injured. They could lose their footing and strain a muscle, roll an ankle or they could fall and be knocked unconscious.
Floodwater is dangerous. Stay safe - never enter floodwater. 

If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Support for flood impacted farmers and producers:
  • Farmers who require support to prepare for flooding, who have been impacted by floods and require assistance or have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
  • For further information on managing crops and livestock after a flood, including budget feed plans, and other support and assistance, visit agriculture.vic.gov.au
Murray River Closure: 
The Murray River is closed to river craft downstream of Tocumwal Bridge to Robinvale.  People and boats are prohibited from entering the river between these locations. Any person on the Murray between these points are to leave the river.  This declaration applies to all residents on both sides of the border.  Neither NSW or Victorian users are permitted on the river at this time.  

Snakes: 
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas.
  • Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater. 
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. 
  • If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately.
Mosquito alert:
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. 
  •  There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.  Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected. 
  • Find out more: Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 
 Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. 
  • When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  •  For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
Blackwater event:   
  • Significant rainfall and flooding can cause water quality issues like low-oxygen (hypoxic) blackwater and blue green algae. 
  • High levels of organic matter have been washed into waterways and, combined with warm weather, can cause oxygen levels in the water to drop. This can harm or cause the death of fish and crayfish. 
  • River managers and scientists monitor rivers for water quality issues and work to reduce the impacts of a blackwater event where they can. 
  • Low levels of dissolved oxygen are recorded at several locations across northern Victoria and in the Murray River. 
  • The scale of the current flooding means water quality will not improve quickly.
  • Any fish death event in Victoria should be reported to the EPA by calling 1300 372 842
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray River and its tributaries.

  • The Murray River at Barham peaked at 6.21 metres on Wednesday 26 October and is currently at 6.14 metres and steady, with major flooding. The Murray River at Barham is likely to remain above the major flood level (6.10 metres) through to the end of the week.
Some properties remain isolated due to standing water across many areas. Aircraft (including drones) are being used to determine the extent of water inundation across the area. Emergency services personnel are assessing impacts on affected properties caused by overtopping and levee breeches. 

Emergency services are assessing and reinforcing existing levees as required, protecting isolated assets and providing relief to local communities and primary producers.  The evaluation of potential impacts on critical infrastructure and townships remains a focus.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  •  Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting http://www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/ 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - do not drive through floodwater.
  • Stay away from damaged and flooded buildings, fallen or damaged trees and powerlines, and damaged roads until authorities advise they are safe.

Never allow children to play in or near floodwater!
  • Flooded rivers and creeks can contain toxic chemicals such as petrol, oil, animal or human waste, pesticides and runoff from roads, paddocks, drains and even sewage overflows (poo and wee and anything else that is flushed down the toilet). 
  • Raw sewage and floodwater can contain bacteria and viruses like E Coli, Giardia and Hepatitis A. Swallowing even a small amount of this can make your children sick. Open cuts, grazes and wounds can easily become infected.
  • Barbed wire, rubbish, branches, broken glass, metal fragments and other loose items can all find their way into floodwater. These objects can cause a child to get tangled or severely injured. They could lose their footing and strain a muscle, roll an ankle or they could fall and be knocked unconscious.    

Floodwater is dangerous. Stay safe - never enter floodwater. 

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Support for flood impacted farmers and producers:
  • Farmers who require support to prepare for flooding, who have been impacted by floods and require assistance or have urgent animal welfare needs, please contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
  • For further information on managing crops and livestock after a flood, including budget feed plans, and other support and assistance, visit agriculture.vic.gov.au
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels may cause flooding in areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Some agricultural land may be vulnerable to flooding. Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground. 
  • Local roads and bridges may be closed.
  • Breeches and overtopping of levees have occurred, leading to additional impacts particularly in Murrabit West and Benjeroop.
  • There is currently no access for any vehicles between Murrabit West and Benjeroop due to water inundation along Murrabit West Road. 
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
Murray River closure: 
The Murray River is closed to river craft downstream of Tocumwal Bridge to Robinvale.  People and boats are prohibited from entering the river between these locations. Any person on the Murray between these points are to leave the river.  This declaration applies to all residents on both sides of the border.  Neither NSW or Victorian users are permitted on the river at this time.   

Snakes:
  • There are a high number of snakes active in flooded areas.
  • Snakes may look for shelter and food in flooded areas. 
  • Be careful around houses, storage sheds and other buildings near floodwater.  
  • Call DELWP on 136 186 for advice on snake controllers in your area. 
  • If someone is bitten, call 000 immediately. 
Mosquito alert:
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases.  
  • There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.   
  • Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected.  
  • Find out more, visit:  Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 
Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. 
  • When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  • For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
Blackwater event:  
Significant rainfall and flooding can cause water quality issues like low-oxygen (hypoxic) blackwater and blue green algae. High levels of organic matter have been washed into waterways and, combined with warm weather, can cause oxygen levels in the water to drop. This can harm or cause the death of fish and crayfish. River managers and scientists monitor rivers for water quality issues and work to reduce the impacts of a blackwater event where they can. Low levels of dissolved oxygen are recorded at several locations across northern Victoria and in the Murray River. The scale of the current flooding means water quality will not improve quickly. Any fish death event in Victoria should be reported to the EPA by calling 1300 372 842. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa.

This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 1.25 pm Monday 07/11/2022.

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT KIALLA WEST

River levels are continuing to ease along the Seven Creeks with minor flooding likely to continue at KiallaWest into Wednesday.

No significant rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days

Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa.

The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is currently at 4.57 metres and falling very slowly, with minor flooding. 

The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is likely to remain above the minor flood level (4.50 m) during Tuesday and into Wednesday

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.  
Community Information

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent. More information on how to reduce your risk Visit Better Health (Mosquitoes) 

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases. 

In flood-affected areas, there are now many cases of gastro (gastroenteritis, diarrhoea) causing people to get very sick. For information on how to prevent gastro visit Better Health (Gastro)
