properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Barmah, Barmah East and Lower Moira. 

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 3.42pm Monday 07/11/2022. 

  • Major Flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Barmah. The river level is currently at 7.09 meters and steady, above the major flood level of 7.00 meters
  • SES in conjunction with CMA estimate that as the river level falls to around 6.8 meters the water pressure on the levee bank will subside. At 6.8 meters the risk will reduce and pumping of water will no longer be required. 
  • Moderate flooding is currently occurring upstream of Barmah to Lake Hume.
  • Hume Dam is currently releasing 75,644ML/D as at 3pm 8th November.

Rainfall is predicted later in the week. Please monitor all conditions-water levels may change as the result of rainfall. 
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

The wet ground conditions have resulted in many trees falling without warning.  If it gets windy, trees will become more unstable and deadly.  Never park, take shelter or camp under a tree.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Be aware of the increased likelihood of trees falling due to the very wet ground, especially in windy conditions. Never shelter under trees.  
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.

If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Impacts in your area:

  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.    
  • Check the Vic Traffic website (Vic traffic) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Flood levels may remain above floor level of a single-storey home.
  • Based on historic data, this flood has had a similar impact as the 1993 flood.
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 04:30 pm or as the situation changes.

There is a Community Meeting at the Barmah Community Hall - Schier Street, Barmah on Saturday 5th November at 11.00am.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
Community notification:

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent More information on hoe to reduce your risk visit Better Health (Mosquitoes)

For information on how to prevent gastro visit Better Health (Gastro)

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases.

Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home.  Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas.   

The Picola to Barmah Road is now open, however shallow water may still cover some parts of the road. The Nathalia relief centre is still open at the Nathalia Community Centre, 42 Robinson St, Nathalia operating 10am - 2pm, for after hours phone 0419717147.

This is a Final Flash Flood Warning for Bacchus Marsh.
  • The immediate threat of flash flooding has passed. 
  • Dangerous hazards including floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees may still be present.
The threat of flooding is reduced. You can now return to normal activity, but be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area.
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is dangerous - do not enter floodwater. 
  • Find alternative travel routes if roads or underpasses are flooded. 
  • Be aware of driving hazards, such as mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees. 

If your home or business has been flooded: 
  • Check for building damage before you enter. 
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use. 
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible. 

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Buildings have been impacted by flooding in this area. 
  • Flash flooding is now longer impacting Darley, Maddingley and Bacchus Marsh.
  • The flood levels in Korkuperrimul Creek have fallen. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

This will be the last warning issued for this flood. 

Flood information: 
  • Further flash flood information for some areas can be found in Local Flood Guides. 
  • For river heights check the Bureau of Meteorology website or phone 1300 659 217. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Campaspe River downstream of Rochester.

  • Minor flooding is continuing along the Campaspe River at Echuca. 
  • River levels are generally easing along the Campaspe River with continued minor flooding at Echuca. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River downstream of Rochester. 
  • The Campaspe River at Echuca is currently at 94.16 m ADH (Australian Height Datum) and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 
  • The river is expected to remain above the minor flood level (92.80 m AHD) for the remainder of Monday through to Wednesday.
  • This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued Friday 4th November at 12.17pm.
The latest community newsletter from Monday 7th November is available here: Community Newsletter Monday 7th November - Campaspe/Murray

An Emergency Warning remains current for parts of Echuca and Echuca Village, where is is not safe to return.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Mosquito alert:
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/protect-yourself-mosquito-borne-disease.  

What you can do: 
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing.
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin.
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens.
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Leave all uninjured wildlife alone as they are likely to be fatigued and stressed. If you see animals that appear injured or caught in flood water, call 136186 or via the Wildlife Emergency app.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message has been issued for Bogong Village and Falls Creek.


  • A landslide has occurred on the Bogong High Plains Road above Bogong Village.
  • There is a large active slow moving landslide on the Bogong High Plains Road in the area near Spring Saddle Track above Bogong Village.
  • After recent heavy rainfall, cracking has been identified in the area around Spring Saddle Track and debris has been moving from below the track onto Bogong High Plains Road.
  • Further rainfall is forecast which could increase movement of the landslide.
  • An emergency alley track has been completed for Emergency Services access.
  • Rectification works are in progress. 

The Bogong High Plains Road is closed from Mount Beauty to Falls Creek to all traffic - until further notice, and will not reopen until deemed safe. 

An exclusion zone has been established, prohibiting entry into the area defined in the map which is available at Bogong Landslip - Exclusion Zone. Access to this area is strictly prohibited and is a threat to your life if you enter. 
 
Avoid the area. Stay clear of fallen earth and trees, blocked or damaged roads. Be aware or other hazards caused by the landslip. Do not enter the exclusion zone.
What you should do:
  • Stay away from the impacted area.
  • If another landslide occurs, act quickly.
  • If you are outside when a landslide occurs, move quickly and keep clear of embankments, trees, power lines and poles. 
  • If you are inside, move to the part of the building that is furthest away from the the approaching landslide and take shelter under a table or bench.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
Travelling
  • Plan you trip in advance - travel may take longer due to closed roads and poor driving conditions.
  • There will be no public access to Falls Creek and Bogong Village as the Bogong High Plains Road remains closed.
  • The Bogong High Plains Road south of Falls Creek is open to local traffic only, accessible via the Omeo Highway. 
Impacts in your area:
The landslide has resulted in:
  • Fallen trees and branches.
  • Dangerous road conditions.
  • Mud and debris on the road.
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 14/11/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#viclandslide).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is for Echuca and Echuca Village.
  • An evacuation warning remains current. It is still not safe to return.
  • Dangerous floodwater and standing water remains in Echuca, continue to avoid flood-affected areas. 
  • It may not be safe to return for one to two weeks. 
MURRAY RIVER
  • Major flooding is occurring at Echuca.
  • Along the Murray River at Echuca and Moama, river levels are slowly receding, with major flooding likely to continue until around Wednesday.
  • The Murray River at Echuca peaked at 94.98 metres AHD on Wednesday 26 October and is currently at 94.55 metres AHD and falling slowly, with major flooding. The Murray River at Echuca is likely to remain above the major flood level (94.40 metres) through to Wednesday.
CAMPASPE RIVER
  • Minor flooding is continuing along the Campaspe River at Echuca. 
  • River levels are generally easing along the Campaspe River with continued minor flooding at Echuca. 
  • The Campaspe River at Echuca is currently at 94.16 m AHD (Australian Height Datum) and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 
  • The river is expected to remain above the minor flood level (92.80 m AHD) for the remainder of Monday through to Wednesday
The latest community newsletter from Monday 7 November is available here: Community Newsletter

It is not safe for people to return to Echuca and Echuca Village. If you have not evacuated, you should now shelter in the highest location possible.

The Echuca Emergency Relief Centre (Echuca South Basketball Stadium located at 244 High street, Echuca) can be accessed by people if required. Open between 9:00am - 5:00pm.
What you should do:

If you have not already evacuated:
  • Stay inside and be aware of changing conditions.   
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time. 
  • If floodwater comes inside, move to a higher point such as a kitchen bench or second storey.   
  • Follow your emergency plan, if you have one.   
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so.   
  • Emergency services may not be able to help you.  
  • Flood water is impacting sewerage systems in Echuca. Residents should limit water usage where possible - this will reduce the volume being sent to sewerage while flood levels are high.  
  • Most levees are not designed for the level of flooding we are currently experiencing, so there is potential for a breach or failure. 
  • Avoid being on or near the levee in Echuca township to reduce the risk of erosion and/or damage to the levee.  
  • To prevent the sewer network being overwhelmed, all Echuca residents should  minimise their use of anything that produces wastewater, including toilets, showers, baths, dishwashers and washing machines.  
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Flood Recovery Hotline 1800 560 760 for assistance. 
  • For emergency assistance from the SES, call 132 500. 
  • Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency.  
If you have already evacuated:
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at Echuca Emergency Relief Centre, open between 9:00am- 5:00pm (Echuca South Basketball Stadium located at 244 High Street, Echuca) so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

This evacuation warning is likely to remain in place for one to two weeks.

For commercial and recreational users of the Murray River: The NSW State Emergency Service have declared an emergency area on the Murray River for areas downstream of Tocumwal Road Bridge to Barham Bridge under the State Emergency Services Act 1989 (NSW) (SES Act). Do not enter the emergency area. This applies to all commercial and recreational users. Visit the NSW SES website for information: https://www.ses.nsw.gov.au/news/all-news/2022/emergency-area-declared-murray-river/
Impacts in your area:
  • Flood levels remain above the floor of single-storey homes. 
  • Flooded roads remain closed to all traffic due to flooding over the road, except emergency vehicles. Victoria Police will enforce road closures - no unauthorised access permitted.
  • Standing water remains in areas that have been inundated. If it was removed, it would quickly refill. The standing water is toxic.
  • Areas near the affected location may lose services including power, water, sewerage and phone coverage due to flooding.  
  • The drinking water in Echuca is safe for all drinking, bathing and cleaning purposes. No boil water advisories are in place. Current poor raw water quality may impact the treatment processes at the Water Treatment Plant. The quality of the raw water is likely to be an ongoing issue. If you are able to do so, it is recommended to put 20-40 litres of drinking water aside in suitable containers to meet the drinking water needs of your household. 
  • You may see animals attempting to move to higher ground, including snakes. Leave all uninjured wildlife alone and they are likely to be fatigued and stressed. If you see animals that appear to be injured or caught in floodwater, call 136 186 or advise via the wildlife emergency app. 
Mosquito Alert
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at  betterhealth.vic.gov.au/protect-yourself-mosquito-borne-disease.  

What you can do: 
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing.   
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin.  
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens.  
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Loddon River, Loddon Weir to Kerang.

Minor flooding is continuing to ease at Appin South and Kerang and minor flooding has eased downstream of Loddon Weir.

No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days and flood levels are likely to ease.

Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang:
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang. 
  • The Loddon River downstream of Loddon Weir is currently at 3.23 metres and falling, below the minor flood level (3.30 m).
  • The Loddon River at Appin South is currently at 3.09 metres and steady, with minor flooding. 
  • The Loddon River at Appin South is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.80 m) for the next few days.
  • The Loddon River at Murray Valley Hwy Bridge (Kerang) is currently at 77.20 m Australian Height Datum (AHD) and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 
  • The Loddon River at Murray Valley Hwy Bridge (Kerang) is expected to remain above the minor flood level (77.00 m AHD) for the next few days.
A Watch and Act remains current for Lower Bendigo and Bullock Creeks with moderate flooding impacts occurring in Kerang East. 

The latest community newsletter from Saturday 5 November is available here: Community Newsletter
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • A Watch and Act remains current for Lower Bendigo and Bullock Creeks with moderate flooding impacts occurring in Kerang East. 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.

There are a number of health hazards as a result of floodwater for you to be aware of. These can be found in more detail in the community newsletter and include: 

Mosquito alert: 
  •  Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 

Infectious diseases:
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. 
  •  There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.  Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected. 
  • Find out more: Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 

 Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. 
  • When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  •  For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 
Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

  • Minor flooding has eased along the Mitta Mitta River at Tallandoon. 
  • Mitta Mitta River downstream of Lake Dartmouth: No further flooding is expected along the Mitta Mitta River downstream of Lake Dartmouth. 
  • The Mitta Mitta River at Tallandoon is currently at 4.13 metres and falling slowly, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Mitta Mitta River at Tallandoon is expected to remain below the minor flood level (4.20 m). 
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: the Murray River downstream of Liparoo to Wentworth
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Liparoo to Wentworth

This Watch and Act message updates the Watch and Act flood warning issued yesterday afternoon. 

  • Moderate flooding is occurring at Wentworth, Swan Hill and Boundary Bend
  • MAJOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SWAN HILL THIS WEEK BELOW THE 1975 FLOOD LEVEL
  • MAJOR FLOODING HIGHER THAN THE 1975 FLOOD POSSIBLE AT WAKOOL JUNCTION, BOUNDARY BEND, EUSTON, MILDURA, AND WENTWORTH
  • Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray and Edwards Rivers and their tributaries.
  • Releases from the Hume Dam combined with Kiewa River flows have caused moderate flooding along the Murray River at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.
  • Murray River at Echuca and Moama, river levels are slowly receding, with major flooding likely to continue until around Wednesday. 
  • At Torrumbarry, river levels are expected to remain steady due to continuing breakout flows, with major flooding forecast into mid November.
  • At Barham, a major flood peak was observed around 26 October following a series of renewed rises. River levels are falling slowly, with major flooding likely to continue through to the end of the week. 
  • At Swan Hill, moderate flooding is occurring, with major flooding similar to the 1975 flood possible around mid November. The Murray River at Swan Hill may peak near the major flood level (4.70 m) during Thursday, with major flooding.
  • At Boundary Bend: The Murray River at Boundary Bend may exceed the major flood level (9.00 metres) around Friday 11 November. The river level may reach near 9.10 metres around 15-17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • At Euston: The Murray River at Euston may exceed the moderate flood level (9.80 metres, 51.60 metresAHD) around 13-16 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (10.30 metres, 52.10 metres AHD) around 16-18 November and reach around 10.40 metres (52.24 metres AHD) around 19-22 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • At Mildura: The Murray River at Mildura Weir is likely to exceed the minor flood level (36.00 metres AHD) during Tuesday and exceed the moderate flood level (37.50 metres AHD) around 21-25 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (38.50 metres AHD) and may reach 38.60 metres AHD around the end of November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • At Wentworth: The Murray River at Wentworth may exceed the major flood level (33.88 m AHD) and reach 34.20 m AHD around the first week of December, with major flooding.
Along the Edward River, 
  • Moderate flooding continues at Deniliquin, Stevens Weir and Moulamein. 
  • At Moulamein the river is approaching a peak near 5.90 meters from the combined flows along the Edward River and Billabong Creek. Renewed rises are likely along the Edward River through mid to late November as upstream Murray River flows arrive. The Edward River at Moulamein is peaking near 5.90 metres, with moderate flooding. Renewed rises are possible from mid to late November onwards.
  • At Deniliquin: Renewed rises are occurring along the Edward River at Deniliquin, where the river level may reach near 9.00 metres around 14-16 November, with moderate flooding.
  • At Stevens Weir: The Edward River at Stevens Weir Downstream is likely to reach around 6.50 metres around 16-18 November, with moderate flooding.

Wakool River: 
  • Major flooding is occurring at Wakool Junction. The Murray River at Wakool Junction may reach near 12.00 metres around 13-15 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • Significant breakout flows from Torrumbarry have spilled into the Wakool River. These flows, combined with floodwaters from the Murray and Edward Rivers, have caused major flooding at Wakool Junction and may cause major flooding downstream at Boundary Bend, Euston, Mildura and Wentworth, with levels higher than the 1975 flood event. 
  • Forecasts will be progressively refined once upstream flood peaks along the Murray River and its tributaries are observed.
  • Flood operations are being conducted by the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (MDBA) at Hume Dam to manage inflows from the upper Murray, Mitta Mitta River and other tributaries. MDBA are working closely with the Bureau and WaterNSW to plan release strategies.

Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Be prepared to move vehicles, livestock and farming equipment to higher ground if still safe to do
  • If necessary, lift household or shed items (including farm chemicals) on top of tables, chairs, benches or up to high shelves. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never  play or swim in floodwater.
Watch the latest video Flood update
  • To watch today's Incident Controller and VICTORIA POLICE information update video go to or click https://youtu.be/V86cUFDtmBA
  • To watch a YouTube video Sunday night's Community Meeting in Mildura, including Questions and Answers,  go to https://youtu.be/JbjNCvrBNvE
Attend one of the coming community information sessions or meetings:
  • Over 120 people attended the Nangiloc & Colignan drop in session today.
  • Lindsay Point drop in CMA session Wed 9.11.22  1pm at the Crackling Plant 
  • Merbein drop in session, Wed 9.11.22 4pm-5.30pm Merbein Community Hub / library 
  • Nichols Point Mon 14.11.22 drop in session 4pm-5.30 pm, Nichols Point Primary School 
  • Red Cliffs drop in session Tue 15.11.22 3pm-5pm, Red Cliffs Library
  • Note: more being planned across the municipality
Collect the latest Flood Information from Pick-up Points being set up (maps, newsletters, handouts etc) at:
  • Mildura WAVES Visitor Information Centre from Wed 9.11.22 
  • Mildura Library from Wed 9.11.22 
  • Mildura SMECC Sunraysia Mallee Ethnic Communities Council from Wed 9.11.22
Check out the latest Community Newsletter here Mildura Incident Control Centre Newsletter 8.11.22 3 pm

If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for possibly a few weeks in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household and shed items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and shelves.
Impacts in your area:
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
  • Emergency services and Mildura Council are currently working to protect important community infrastructure, such as the Nangiloc Primary School, approved works at the Mildura Waste Water Treatment Plant and the removal of all portable pop-up cafes etc in APEX Park.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home and sheds or garages is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Fishing and boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • The Murray River will be closed through to the South Australian Border to all non-emergency activities in the next few days. SES will update you when that happens via this warning.
  • Parks, hiking tracks and campgrounds in many areas are closed due to flooding. To find out more go to www.parkweb.vic.gov.au/safety/flood-affected-parks. 
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services. 
Road closed? Signs or not.....If it's is flooded, forget it.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
For mental health information and support contact the below organisations: 
Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. 
Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. 
Kids Helpine on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. 
SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

- MAJOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SWAN HILL THIS WEEK BELOW THE 1975 FLOOD LEVEL
- MAJOR FLOODING HIGHER THAN THE 1975 FLOOD POSSIBLE AT WAKOOL JUNCTION, BOUNDARY BEND, EUSTON, MILDURA, AND WENTWORTH
- Rainfall over the past several weeks has caused renewed and prolonged flooding along the Murray and Edwards Rivers and their tributaries.
- Releases from the Hume Dam combined with Kiewa River flows have caused moderate flooding along the Murray River at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.
- Murray River at Echuca and Moama, river levels are slowly receding, with major flooding likely to continue until around Wednesday. 
- At Torrumbarry, river levels are expected to remain steady due to continuing breakout flows, with major flooding forecast into mid November.
- At Barham, a major flood peak was observed around 26 October following a series of renewed rises. River levels are falling slowly, with major flooding likely to continue through to the end of the week. 
- At Swan Hill, moderate flooding is occurring, with major flooding similar to the 1975 flood possible around mid November. The Murray River at Swan Hill may peak near the major flood level (4.70 m) during Thursday, with major flooding.
- At Boundary Bend: The Murray River at Boundary Bend may exceed the major flood level (9.00 metres) around Friday 11 November. The river level may reach near 9.10 metres around 15-17 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
- At Euston: The Murray River at Euston may exceed the moderate flood level (9.80 metres, 51.60 metresAHD) around 13-16 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (10.30 metres, 52.10 metres AHD) around 16-18 November and reach around 10.40 metres (52.24 metres AHD) around 19-22 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
- At Mildura: The Murray River at Mildura Weir is likely to exceed the minor flood level (36.00 metres AHD) during Tuesday and exceed the moderate flood level (37.50 metres AHD) around 21-25 November. The river level may exceed the major flood level (38.50 metres AHD) and may reach 38.60 metres AHD around the end of November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
- At Wentworth: The Murray River at Wentworth may exceed the major flood level (33.88 m AHD) and reach 34.20 m AHD around the first week of December, with major flooding.
Along the Edward River, 
- Moderate flooding continues at Deniliquin, Stevens Weir and Moulamein. 
- At Moulamein the river is approaching a peak near 5.90 meters from the combined flows along the Edward River and Billabong Creek. Renewed rises are likely along the Edward River through mid to late November as upstream Murray River flows arrive. The Edward River at Moulamein is peaking near 5.90 metres, with moderate flooding. Renewed rises are possible from mid to late November onwards.
- At Deniliquin: Renewed rises are occurring along the Edward River at Deniliquin, where the river level may reach near 9.00 metres around 14-16 November, with moderate flooding.
- At Stevens Weir: The Edward River at Stevens Weir Downstream is likely to reach around 6.50 metres around 16-18 November, with moderate flooding.

Wakool River: 
- Major flooding is occurring at Wakool Junction. The Murray River at Wakool Junction may reach near 12.00 metres around 13-15 November, with major flooding. Further rises are possible.
- Significant breakout flows from Torrumbarry have spilled into the Wakool River. These flows, combined with floodwaters from the Murray and Edward Rivers, have caused major flooding at Wakool Junction and may cause major flooding downstream at Boundary Bend, Euston, Mildura and Wentworth, with levels higher than the 1975 flood event. 
- Forecasts will be progressively refined once upstream flood peaks along the Murray River and its tributaries are observed.
- Flood operations are being conducted by the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (MDBA) at Hume Dam to manage inflows from the upper Murray, Mitta Mitta River and other tributaries. MDBA are working closely with the Bureau and WaterNSW to plan release strategies. 



Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River to Tocumwal.

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 4.19pm Monday 07/11/2022.
 
Releases from the Hume Dam combined with Kiewa River flows have caused moderate flooding along the Murray River at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.

Flood operations are being conducted by the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (MDBA) at Hume Dam to manage inflows from the upper Murray, Mitta Mitta River and other tributaries. MDBA are working closely with the Bureau and Water NSW to plan release strategies.

Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal:

Moderate flooding is occurring at Albury, Corowa, Yarrawonga and Tocumwal.

The Murray River at Albury peaked at 5.39 metres around 03:00 pm Wednesday 02 November and is currently at 5.28 metres and slowly falling, with moderate flooding.

The Murray River at Corowa peaked at 7.55 metres around 04:00 pm Saturday 05 November and is currently at 7.48 metres and and slowly falling, with moderate flooding.

The Murray River at Yarrawonga Downstream peaked at 7.13 metres around 11:45 am Saturday 05 November and is currently at 6.95 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. The river level at Yarrawonga Downstream may remain around 7.00 metres for the next few days.

The Murray River at Tocumwal peaked at 6.95 metres around 02:45 pm Monday 07 November and is currently at 6.91 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. 

The river level at Tocumwal is likely to remain around 6.90 metres through to Wednesday, with moderate flooding.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.

Community Information

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent for more information visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes)

 For information about gastro prevention, visit: Better Health (Gastro)

Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home.  Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Flood Advice is being issued for Loddon River downstream of Kerang.

River levels are elevated along the Loddon River downstream of Kerang.

  • Breeches and overtopping of levees have occurred over the past week leading to  impacts on buildings, farmland and roads in the Murrabit West and Benjeroop and into areas north of Kerang.
  • There is currently no access for 4WD vehicles between Murrabit West and Benjeroop due to water inundation along Murrabit West Road. 
  • High water levels continue to move downstream with impacts on properties and surrounding agricultural land.  
No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

The latest community newsletter from Saturday 5 November is available here: Community Newsletter
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters. Check the VicTraffic website for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Stay away from damaged and flooded buildings, fallen or damaged trees and powerlines, and damaged roads until authorities advise they are safe.
  • A community newsletter has been developed to assist with any questions locals may have. Go to: Community Newsletter - Gannawarra Shire
If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Contact Gannawarra Shire Council or go to https://www.emergency.vic.gov.au/relief/#relief_assistance for relief and recovery information.
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.
  • Protect your health and safety when cleaning. Wear strong boots, gloves and protective clothing and wash your hands and clothes regularly.
  • If you have lost power for a prolonged time due to flooding, you should not consume food from your fridge or freezer. Throw out food that has touched floodwater or has an unusual smell, colour or texture, do not taste or cook it.
  • Electricity: Only turn on power at the mains if water has not entered your property. Have wiring and appliances tested and tagged before use.
  • Gas: If your home has been impacted by floodwater, do not attempt to turn the gas supply back on. Gas lines may contain water and must be checked by the distribution company. Contact details can be found on the top right of your gas bill.
Impacts in your area:

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • The Kerang-Murrabit Road is impacted by floodwater between Gale Lane and West Road. 
  • Parts of the Murray Valley Highway is impacted by floodwater.
  • Other roads and bridges may be impacted by floodwater.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.

Exclusion Zones:
Exclusion zones are in place due to hazardous waterways and debris flow. It is expected that many of these will remain in place until late November. These include:
  • Lake Charm
  • Kangaroo Lake
  • Lake Meran
  • All waters of Gunbower Creek that are within the Shire of Gannawarra.
Further information can be found at: https://transportsafety.vic.gov.au/maritime-safety/newsroom.

There are a number of health hazards as a result of floodwater for you to be aware of. 
These can be found in more detail in the community newsletter and include:  

Mosquito alert 
  • Your only protection against mosquitoes and the diseases they can carry is to avoid mozzie bites. 
  • For more information and to learn how to protect yourself and your family, visit: Better Health (Mosquitoes) 
Infectious diseases: 
  • Floodwater can contain sewage and other waste which can cause infections or diseases. 
  • There are a range of things you can do to reduce your risk of illness.  
  • Seek medical attention if you have any symptoms of gastro, flu-like symptoms, or if any wounds become red and infected. 
  • Find out more:  Better Health (Emergencies - floods) 

Mould: 
  • Flooding, excess moisture and pooled water can cause mould growth in your home. 
  • When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell.  
  •  For information on how to clean up and remove mould, visit Better Health (mould removal at home) 

Flood-affected septic systems: 
If your property has been affected by floodwater, a licensed plumber should assess your septic system for safety and function. A damaged system could back up into your house or garden. Parts of the system that may be damaged include: 
  • Shallow PVC pipes that may be blocked 
  • Tanks and sumps 
  • Disposal/irrigation system and pipework 
  • Pumps and equipment with electrical components    
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This is a Final Flood Watch for Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton .

This is an update for the advice issued at 1.02pm Monday, 07/11/2022

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT DOWNSTREAM (D/S) LAKE EILDON, TRAWOOL, SEYMOUR,MURCHISON, SHEPPARTON AND MCCOYS BRIDGE

Minor flooding is continuing along the Goulburn River at Downstream Lake Eildon, Trawool, Seymour, Murchison, Shepparton and McCoys Bridge.

Goulburn Murray Water has advised that releases from Lake Eildon will be around 20,000 ML/d during Tuesday, below the moderate flood flow.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Tuesday, rainfall totals of up to 12 mm have been recorded within the Goulburn River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday.

Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton.

The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently at 9.39 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 

The Goulburn River at Murchison will remain above the minor flood level (9.00 m) during Tuesday and into Wednesday.

The Goulburn River at Shepparton is currently at 10.31 metres and falling slowly, with minor flooding. 

The Goulburn River at Shepparton will remain above the minor flood level (9.50 m) during Tuesday and into Wednesday
The threat of flooding is reduced. You can now return to normal activity, but be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning issued for this flood.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Broken Creek at Walshs Bridge.

This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 4.27 pm , Friday 04/11/2022


MINOR FLOODING TO CONTINUE AT WALSHS BRIDGE AND NATHALIA FOR THE NEXT FEW DAYS

Minor flooding is expected to continue along the Broken Creek between Walshs Bridge and Nathalia for the next few days.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Monday, no significant rainfall totals have been observed across the Broken Creek catchment. 

No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few day



Minor flooding is occurring along the Broken Creek. Minor flooding is expected to continue at Walsh Bridge for the next few days.The Broken Creek at Nathalia is currently at 1.89 metres and steady, with minor flooding. 

The Broken Creek at Nathalia is expected to remain above the minor flood level (1.50 m) for the next few days.


Updated community information: 

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent. More information on how to reduce your risk visit Better Health (Mosquitoes)

In flood-affected areas, there are now many cases of gastro (gastroenteritis, diarrhoea) causing people to get very sick. For information on how to prevent illness visit Better Health (Gastro)

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases.

Flood waters may contain sewerage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home. Contact with sewerage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas.

The wet ground conditions have resulted in many trees falling without warning. 

If it gets windy, trees will become more unstable and deadly. Never park, take shelter or camp under a tree. 

Do not camp close to rivers or creeks.

Unexpected river rises are very likely after even small amounts of rainfall.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

In the VicEmergency App, add a watch zone for your campsite and regularly check emergency broadcasters via car radio if necessary. 

What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Sevens Creek to Euroa

This is an update, replacing the Advice message issued at 1.25pm Monday,  07/11/2022. 

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT KIALLA WEST

River levels are continuing to ease along the Seven Creeks with minor flooding likely to continue at Kialla West into Wednesday.

No significant rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days


Community information: 

Mould: When returning to your home after a flood, be aware of any visible mould or a musty smell. High mould levels are likely if the house has been flooded for more than two days. For information on Mould and how to safely clean up visit Better Health (Mould)

Be aware that mosquito borne disease hazards are present so please cover up and use repellent. More information on how to reduce your risk visit Better Health (Mosquitoes)

Do not put Lithium-ion batteries in with general rubbish. Dispose of via a municipal battery collection facility.  Damaged or defective batteries can overheat, catch fire or explode releasing projectiles and can release toxic gases. 


For information on how to prevent gastro visit Better Health (Gastro)

Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home.  Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas. 
The wet ground conditions have resulted in many trees falling without warning.  If it gets windy, trees will become more unstable and deadly.  Never park, take shelter or camp under a tree.   

Do not camp close to rivers or creeks.     

Unexpected river rises are very likely after even small amounts of rainfall.   

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert. Never enter floodwater.   

In the VicEmergency App, add a watch zone for your campsite and regularly check emergency broadcasters via car radio if necessary.
What you should do: 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one.
When returning home 
  • Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property.  
  • If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician.  
  • If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician.  
  • For more information visit: https://esv.vic.gov.au/safety-education/emergencies/electrical-emergency/ 
  • If cleaning after damage has occurred, protect your health and safety. 
  • Protect your lungs by wearing a N95 or P2 mask.  
  • Wear strong boots, gloves and protective clothing and wash your hands and clothes regularly.  
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.  
  • Smelly black water can be reported to EPA on 1800 560 760

Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and flooding may still affect areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may still be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Low lying caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2022 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.  
Recovery: 
Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: 
  • Register for clean up on private property; 
  • Navigating financial and other support 
  • Access to temporary accommodation 
  • Mental health and wellbeing support 
The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 or visit www.erv.vic.gov.au for further information. 

For life-threatening emergencies, call Triple Zero (000) immediately. 
For emergency assistance during floods call 132 500 for SES assistance.

Health Messaging 
  • Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. 
  • Floodwaters may contain sewage and other toxic waste and can also overflow into your home.  Contact with sewage can make people sick, so clean and disinfect any impacted areas. 
  • Stay out of the water - skin contact with floodwater or mud can cause illness and skin infections. Cover cuts and if you are injured during your clean up; clean the wound and contact your doctor immediately.  
  • Private water supplies may also be contaminated from floodwater, debris and chemicals. If your water supply tastes, looks or smells unusual, do not use it for drinking, preparing food, and do not give it to animals.  
  • Medicines, stored at home and affected by flood water may now be unsafe and extreme caution should be taken in trying to salvage any medicines. 
  • Mosquitoes can also breed rapidly in stagnant waters. Drain any water from containers such as plant pots, tyres, buckets, and roof gutters to control mosquitos around your home. 
  • Flooding can also cause excessive mould growth which must be cleaned up before moving back to your home as it can make you sick. 
  • Any damaged gas or electricity supplies need to be declared safe by a qualified electrician or plumber. 
  • Do not use a portable generator indoors, they can produce carbon monoxide gas which could build up in a confined space and make you sick or be fatal. 
  • Food safety should also be considered and ALL food that has been flood damaged should be thrown away, including canned and packaged foods. 
  • It is important to look after your mental health and that of friends, family and neighbours. If at any time you are worried about your mental health or the mental health of a loved one, call Lifeline 13 11 14 or the Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467.

Register Find Unite - Red Cross 
Red Cross has opened Register.Find.Reunite. and is urging people affected by the Victorian Floods to get in touch with their families and friends. Register.Find.Reunite. helps find and reunite family, friends and loved ones during a disaster. People can register on the Red Cross website at register.redcross.org.au, or by phone at 1800 727 077.
